elements.label: Mike Brunt
elements.bio: My career has spanned Information Technology since 1982, currently I am working on two blockchain-based projects.  In addition, I am a Permaculture Certified designer and an artist, composer and musician.
elements.work: Currently I co-run the Eugene Permaculture Meetup group and am actively involved in several Urban Permaculture projects, in and around Eugene.
elements.statement: The whole concept of bioregionalism is key to our futures everywhere, Bill Mollison saw this years ago and David Holmgren followed up on this with Retro-Suburbia.  We are seeing the failure of globalism and now is the time to get back to our bioregional roots.  Bring back the village.

elements.label: Jon Van Meter
elements.bio: Control room Supervisor for local area television stations, and I communicate daily with News director and assignment editor in the Eugene area with broadcast to Florence, Roseburg and Coos Bay.

elements.label: Department of Bioregion
elements.description: The Department of Bioregion is a 501(c)3 nonprofit and social movement to build a planetary network of interconnected bioregions and bioregional movements.
elements.importence: The Department of Bioregion is a hosting organization for the Regenerate Cascadia activation tour and summit in October of 2023. We hope to use this tour to activate on-the-ground leaders and land stewards with a governance structure able to steward a bioregional regeneration fund.

elements.label: Nate Bade
elements.bio: I am a data scientist from Cascadia!
elements.work: I do some backend work for the Kumu mapping and data organization.
elements.statement: I feel it is a much more economically and socially sensible way to organize the geography of society.

elements.label: Brandon Letsinger
elements.bio: My name is Brandon Letsinger. I'm the founder of CascadiaNow! and the Department of Bioregion, a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization dedicated to building a world of planetary bioregions and interconnected bioregional movements. I am working with Clare Attwell to help convene the Regenerate Cascadia campaign and was a steward in the Salmon Nation edge prize program.

elements.label: Clare Attwell
elements.bio: Clare Attwell has long worked in community cultural development from the local to provincial level, and is also a textile and multi-media artist. She currently works with several local and global communities deeply engaged in every aspect of Earth Regeneration. These include the Design School For Regenerating Earth, Regenerate Cascadia, for which she is the co-founder, and Conversations for a One Planet Region Society, a local, Victoria based non-profit helping to catalyze a Bioregional conversation across the region.
elements.work:
Clare Attwell, B.A., Arts Admin.

Community Artist & Weaver

Since the 1990’s, Clare has worked across scales, from grassroots through to the municipal and provincial levels of decision making, to develop scaffolding to support Community Cultural Development.  Her early work in this area, has informed most of her work since.

Clare currently works with several communities deeply engaged in work involving every aspect of Earth Regeneration. These include the Design School For Regenerating Earth, Regenerate Cascadia, for which she is the co-founder, and Conversations for a One Planet Region Society, a local, Victoria based non-profit helping to catalyze a Bioregional conversation across the region.

Clare is also a textile and multi-media artist. When she is not working on her own art, she works as a community artist, using the arts in imaginative ways to help community groups explore complex issues such as cultural and spiritual identity, including community visioning.  Clare is especially interested in exploring what makes complex systems functional, and in particular, how they relate to organizations and social systems.

https://clareattwellartist.wordpress.com

While I was still in my early teens, I realized that noble efforts that don't connect to people’s hearts, - and where a sense of belonging is absent - , do not create the kind of systems-change required for the world we want.  This was the work I felt called to, despite the fact that no such paid job existed, contrary to appearances.  Thus, for the last 3 decades, I have split my time earning a basic income in unrelated work in order to spend most of my time working as an unpaid weaver, artist in residence, community animator, - using the lens of Community Cultural Development.

My focus has now broadened to using a whole-landscape scale lens for creating the conditions for learning how to ‘bioregion’ together - where the arts, growing food, Earth regeneration, 'yarning' and laughing together, using polycentric governance processes, feature prominently!

“The map is not the territory - A Korzypski

elements.label: Conversations For A One Planet Region Society
elements.description: Through the Conversations for a One Planet Region we want to engage, educate and empower people across the Greater Victoria Region to discuss the challenges and strengths of becoming a One Planet Region.
elements.importence: Our vision is that the Greater Victoria Region achieves social and ecological sustainability, with a high quality of life and a long life in good health for all its citizens, while reducing its ecological footprint to be equivalent to one planet’s worth of biocapacity. Our Mission is very simple: to establish and maintain community-wide conversations on One Planet living and a One Planet Region.

elements.label: midi berry
elements.work: Earth Regenerators, Vivero Steward and Ambassador
elements.statement: Cascadia was the first US bioregion I lived in for two and a half years during the mid-70's and it was already more environmentally aware than other places I'd lived. I fell in love with the land and returned in the early 90's to study for some months when the Process Work group I had been studying with moved from Europe to Portland. My contact with Oregon resumed after immigrating to Southern California in 2001. While participating in Edge Prize I met Cascadia people online and learned about many amazing activities and projects. As a southern outpost of Salmon Nation, I feel an affinity with my northern neighbours. I engage in bioregional work through online networking as well as on-ground and wish to support Regenerate Cascadia however I might be of practical service.

elements.label: Christine Lorenz
elements.bio:
Just starting to learn about regeneration.
Worked in a nonprofit research group in the behavioral sciences.
Massage therapist well.
elements.statement: Yes. That’s why I wanted to join this group on the Cascadia tour.

elements.label: Joe Brewer
elements.bio: Joe has a unique background in physics, math, philosophy, atmospheric science, complexity, and cognitive linguistics. More than a decade ago, he left the academy to trail blaze a path for other practitioners to follow. Awakened to the threat of human-induced climate disruption while pursuing a Ph.D. in atmospheric science, he switched fields and began to work with scholars in the behavioral and cognitive sciences with the hope of helping create large-scale behavior change at the level of global civilization.
elements.work:
He was active with the Center for Complex Systems Research at the University of Illinois studying pattern formation in physical and social systems before joining renowned linguist, George Lakoff, at the Rockridge Institute in Berkeley to analyze political discourse and reveal the structures of meaning in human language.

When Rockridge closed 2008, Joe launched his first social enterprise—a research consultancy called Cognitive Policy Works whose mission was to apply insights from cognitive science to social change. It was here that he built up a global network of collaborators in the nonprofit, governmental, and social impact business domains.

From 2011 to 2017 he was research director at TheRules.org helping social movements as an expert in linguistic framing. He worked closely with Martin Kirk and Alnoor Ladha to coordinate with activists and movement leaders in the reframing of poverty, climate change, capitalism, and key issues around economic development.

In 2012 he joined Lazlo Karafiath to lay foundations for the new field of culture design, culminating in the birth of Culture2 Inc. Along the way, he has contributed to the formation of the International Centre for Earth Simulation—a globally-focused research foundation dedicated to the integration of more than 100 sciences that study the changing Earth.

In 2019, he joined Capital Institute to help manage community relations for the Regenerative Communities Network. The focus was to help create a planetary network of regenerative economies organized at bioregional scales.

In 2020 he founded Earth Regenerators and launched an initiative to regenerate 500,000 hectares of land in Barichara, Colombia while helping seed the formation of the Design School for Regenerating Earth that was established in 2023.

He has spoken at many global conferences on the science of social change and human dimensions of planetary sustainability. And has given workshops on three continents about the workings of the human mind and the strategic tools for designing and enacting positive change in the world.

elements.label: Penny Heiple
elements.bio:
Co-Founder for the Design School for Regenerating Earth. In the Design School for Regenerating Earth, we host online courses on organizational development, landscape restoration, and cooperation. One of our main focuses in the school is facilitating learning exchanges between bioregions doing ecosystem restoration and working to create local living economies in their landscapes. We help to weave dialogues within and between bioregions, and we provide shared language, shared tools, and resources for organizing for regeneration at the landscape scale. 

My work as co-founder includes managing operational activities, finances, administration, technical support, and customer service for the school. In addition, I bring to the school my expertise in project management, community development, prosocial facilitation, biodynamic healing and trauma resolution, unified science, integral philosophy, and regenerative practice. With my comprehensive background in business, finance and project management, I bring a unique combination of heart and organizational expertise to the school.In the Design School for Regenerating Earth, we host online courses on organizational development, landscape restoration, and cooperation. One of our main focuses in the school is facilitating learning exchanges between bioregions doing ecosystem restoration and working to create local living economies in their landscapes. We help to weave dialogues within and between bioregions, and we provide shared language, shared tools, and resources for organizing for regeneration at the landscape scale. My work as co-founder includes managing operational activities, finances, administration, technical support, and customer service for the school. In addition, I bring to the school my expertise in project management, community development, prosocial facilitation, biodynamic healing and trauma resolution, unified science, integral philosophy, and regenerative practice. With my comprehensive background in business, finance and project management, I bring a unique combination of heart and organizational expertise to the school.
elements.work:
Currently living in Barichara, Colombia, and a native of Boulder, Colorado, I have a passion for serving Life and our beautiful planet Earth. I moved to Colombia to live out my dream of helping to regenerate the earth alongside my life partner, Joe Brewer. Together, we are doing ecosystem restoration work and helping to create a local regenerative economy in our bioregion in and around Barichara. We also co-founded the Design School for Regenerating Earth, where we facilitate learning exchanges between bioregions doing ecosystem restoration and working to create local living economies in their landscapes.

I'm passionate about integrating and applying unified science, integral philosophy, regenerative practices, and biodynamic healing and trauma resolution to everything I do. These passions combined with my comprehensive background in operations, project management, accounting, and administration means that I bring a unique combination of heart and organizational expertise to the various initiatives and organizations in which I'm involved.

Please visit this website to learn more about the Design School for Regenerating Earth:
https://design-school-for-regenerating-earth.mn.co/

Please visit this website for more information on my healing practice:
https://pennyheiple.com

elements.label: Benji Ross
elements.bio: Creating space and processes within Earth Regenerators where we can self organize around the purpose of facilitating bioregional learning on a planetary scale. Also exploring ways in which we can create onboarding processes so that anyone seeking a regenerative profession can co-learn the role of the bioregional catalyst with the community and be supported in those efforts. I am designing and hosting sessions, writing posts, publishing videos, and forming connections to further our aims.
elements.work:
So far, life has largely been a meandering inquiry into how human cultures can better relate to our landscapes. That curiosity is why after graduating from business school I became a small scale farmer, rancher, and budding Permaculture practitioner.

After a deep focus on understanding and stewarding landscapes, I came to realize that humans know how to cultivate abundant and resilient ecosystems. Despite our desperate need for that to happen, our ever expanding human built environment and our runaway cultural compulsion towards separation from nature and each other gets in our way.

I am now exploring the ecology of social and cultural systems and how we can discover ways that Homo sapiens can adapt towards better relationships with Earth. Now I ask: How can we as a species rediscover our landscapes as home?

Currently I am part of a community called Earth Regenerators that is cultivating a learning and support ecosystem to explore questions like that. I founded a group within that community called Bioregional Catalysts that is searching for real world examples of communities coming together for landscape scale regeneration to distribute and facilitate replication of what we learn across the planet. We also support individuals and small groups who aspire to convene their communities to see their landscapes as a whole in order to enable local regeneration.

I am a facilitator, a cultural scaffold builder, a content creator, an aspiring storyteller, and I am in service to the planetary scale community commons.

elements.label: Design School for Regenerating Earth
elements.importence: The challenges humanity and the Earth are facing now are extremely complex and unlike anything that has come before in the history of the planet. The good news is that it really is possible to regenerate the Earth at the scales needed. In order to do so, we must consciously and intentionally evolve humanity into a planetary species and learn to cooperate at unprecedented levels. We must organize ourselves around holistic, integrated landscapes known as bioregions, and connect those bioregions into a planetary network of learning exchanges. Members of the Design School are working together on the ground in bioregions while simultaneously building a planetary network and community engaging in this kind of bioregional work. We are learning how to cooperate at the levels needed by practicing and working within Prosocial groups. This enables focused actions to arise with clear design and intent so that we can effectively regenerate at the bioregional scale and create interactions and supports between and across bioregions. All of this being done in service to the regeneration of the entire Planet.

elements.label: Quinn Gerald
elements.bio: Young adult on a bioregional education journey, exploring places, projects, ideas, movements etc. and connecting with folks along the way.. Interested in Agroforestry, Regenerative education to name a couple.. Cascadia based.
elements.work: Nothing too specific yet, mostly trying to bring together folks and weave them into networks I see beginning to emerge. Bio-Cultural restoration camps, community education groups, young people finding their way in regenerative spaces.. How can these type of things integrate into a bioregional learning network? I’m mostly a student (of regeneration).
elements.statement: Well we’ve got to learn to become people of place and structure our societies in appropriate ecological context! I feel getting folks hands in the soil, fingers weaving a basket and doing it together is perhaps the best way to learn this.

elements.label: Kiersten Rossing
elements.bio:
Hey wonderful humans!
My name is Kiersten, and I’m currently based in Portland. 
I am an artist, and am passionate about community uplifting and permaculture, and I’m excited to learn and grow on this journey with you all! 
My love for mother Gaia is expressed through permaculture, herbalism, bioregional regeneration, holistic wellness, song and dance, social forestry, and many many different forms of art.
elements.work:
I am passionate about involving youth to discover their connection with earth and taking part in her regeneration. As a young person, it was synchronistic that I happened to meet the right folks at the right time to connect me with permaculture… I want other young folks emerging into this world to have easier and more mainstream access to permaculture/regenerative living education and experience opportunities.

I am also very interested in and actively learning about herbalism and different holistic wellness practices. Healing our bodies, spirits, and minds is what makes the work we do rooted in an intention that will bring about beautiful changes into our world.

I am an artist, and creative energy flows through me in many various forms! I think lots of community healing and placemaking can happen centered around creation and art, and I’m excited to see how I can share the benefits of tapping into one’s creative potential. I love to create murals, fiber arts, mosaics, natural building, jewelry making, etc. I love how creativity is a wonderful alternative to consumerism, and I think tapping into creative energy and art in different ways allows for beneficial trades and mutual aid to take place!

I have some experience with permaculture gardening, and am continuing to grow in this skill. Tending the earth has opened me up to so much purpose and alignment with what feels like embodying my authentic self. I love community togetherness that occurs when tending the earth and therefore, tending to each other. Working with medicinal plants and herbs has been a wonderful practice for me to communicate and connect with our mother Gaia through these different plant spirits and energies. It’s really amazing how these vessels we call our bodies respond to and communicate with the plant energies we introduce to it!
elements.statement:
We each have a unique perspective to offer when creating the tapestry of our regenerative future here in Cascadia. Diversity within the experiences that are shared and heard is essential for creating the cultural scaffolding on which we will need to stand in order to build and thrive.
That being said, I want to offer my perspective to the mix, as a younger feminine energy in this space.

I think so much healing can occur with creative practices, and my work with art and creative outlets can offer a way for solutions to be born, experiences to be heard, and expressions to be authentic and encouraged!

Medicinal herbs and healing with foods is an important aspect I’m excited to weave into the regeneration of Cascadia as well. Understanding the energy of food and plants, and how they affect us, can open us to a world of connectivity that is essential for saving our ecosystems that provide this healing for us.

elements.label: Steven Morris
elements.bio: Grew up in New Jersey. As a teenager worked on a renewable energy aquaponics project at the Great Swamp Refuge in the 1970s. Got into technology, computers and electronics. Moved to Colorado late 1990s. Now doing work to support the Design School for Regenerating Earth, and living part time in Barichara Colombia.
elements.work: I've been studying complexity with Joe Brewer and Nora Bateson. I've done extensive personal growth work (aka personal healing) and supported many workshops in the production and technology use of them. I also do hands on intuitive energy healing work. I've studied multiple different modalities and integrated them into my offering. I don't do it professionally at this time. Last year i retired from full time event audio / visual production work. I still do that occasionally as well as video recording and editing.

elements.label: Thomas Harun
elements.bio: Currently living in Beaverton/Chakeipi, Atfalati Kalapuya Land, Portland Tri-Met Area, Willamette Valley, Southern Cascadia. Interested in supporting bioregional megaquake resilience, regenerative livelihoods, and climate justice. Professional background as a teacher and in non-profit environmental media.
elements.work:
I'm a director of Branch Out, non-profit publisher of online climate journalism, headquartered in Cascadia.

Our newest project, Climate Wiki, is launching its public beta test tomorrow!

You are invited to collaborate with us to develop Climate Wiki's knowledge commons as a set of tools for effective activism and stewardship.
elements.statement: The incoming Megaquake will strike across the Cascadia Bioregion and is a stunning example of why bioregional-scale regeneration is necessary for solidarity and adaptation. Everything from food sovereignty to watershed health, affordable housing, treaty rights, bioregional supply chains, and replacing fossil fuels is at stake.

elements.label: Vivero
elements.description: Vivero is a trust-based regenerative finance platform that nurtures healthy community, people and projects. It changes the face of traditional economics by naming, encouraging and valuing many forms of capital flow between people, their programs and projects. Vivero members interact and collaborate directly with each other and decide collectively where gifts will go. Non-financial community contributors are recognised alongside those who give $s. Beneficiaries and their projects are visible in a mobile / web-based Vivero app which has been successfully prototyped in Earth Regenerators. Vivero giving and receiving is tracked transparently.
elements.importence: Vivero’s open source architecture and technology is designed to branch and network out into bioregions, to be adapted and shaped to specific community needs and local contexts including — if desired — giving a bridge between fiat and crypto. Vivero project incubation and syntropic storytelling brings together diverse community voices to share and collaborate in a collective action-learning path that all members are welcomed to walk together. The app-based community noticeboard keeps people and projects connected.

elements.label: Brad Sander
elements.bio: Living in Colorado but connections to Cascadia through previous life as a Paraglider, interested to see if anyone from that world will come through this portal the way I have.. way better to live fully on the ground than fly through the sky.
elements.statement: I'm not sure if my work is, other than the fractally of course, my work is connected to your work is connected to all work..

elements.label: Michkael Baker
elements.bio: Greetings, I'm Michael Baker, also known as a Community Orchestrator. Over the past 15 years, my journey has been dedicated to understanding and designing communication, sharing, and exchange systems that empower individuals and local communities to establish decentralized economic systems. My passion lies in assisting fellow entrepreneurs in mastering the art of collaboration and creating innovative business models, open-source technologies, and social systems that benefit communities and their environment. Having had the privilege of founding and leading various businesses, my current focus centers on nurturing changemakers within local communities. I'm dedicated to leveraging community intelligence technologies to support locally connected, decentralized economic systems through initiatives like community innovation hubs or community action centers, with a focus on promoting regenerative agriculture, community entrepreneurship, immersive health education, and community-owned real estate development
elements.work:
Our work revolves around empowering the creation and establishment of locally interconnected economic systems. Through the Community Resource Tree Foundation, I facilitate the development of innovative tools and technologies that enable communities to collaborate in real-time resource mapping. These technologies, such as the Community Intelligence Engine, act as a community and economic accelerator, harnessing the power of data and collaboration.

We provide a platform for communities to pool resources, exchange goods and services with a multi-currency approach, and address pressing issues collectively. Our vision is to create vibrant, self-sustaining local economies, fostering cooperative entrepreneurship and ownership. With a focus on education and engagement, we empower individuals to become catalysts for change within their communities.
elements.statement:
The significance of my work and how that applies to the principles of bioregionalism is in the impact on the future our natural ecosystems. By harnessing advanced technologies like the Community Resource Tree and Community Intelligence Engine, we unlock the potential to gather, analyze, and apply data in unprecedented ways. This real-time collaboration and resource mapping offer the region a powerful tool to address complex challenges, whether environmental, economic, or social.

Bioregionalism underscores the importance of understanding the unique characteristics and interconnectedness of the Cascadia bioregion. My work allows us to aggregate data from various regions, bringing together diverse perspectives and solutions. It fosters an ecosystem of cooperation, enabling resource exchange and problem-solving on a local and regional scale.

In essence, our collective mission aligns seamlessly with the principles of bioregionalism, providing the tools needed to build a sustainable and prosperous future for the Cascadia bioregion.

elements.label: Rick Lukens
elements.bio: Richard Lukens has spent the past four decades orchestrating world-class live events to support humanitarian, environmental and social causes. He has assisted in the production of some of some of the most important cause-related events in history, such as the first live interactive "Space-Bridge" between the former Soviet Union and the United States, the Live Aid concert, the White House Conference on Global Climate Change, events for the United Nations and many others.
elements.work: Local and global special event production
elements.statement: I am bringing climate change and sustainability educational programs and public events to Fort Worden in Port Townsend, Washington

elements.label: Paul E Nelson
elements.bio: Poet & interviewer Paul E. Nelson is the son of a labor activist father and Cuban immigrant mother. Born on Chicago’s west side in 1961, he’s lived in King County since 1988. He founded the Cascadia Poetics LAB (formerly SPLAB (Seattle Poetics LAB)) & the Cascadia Poetry Festival. Since 1993, CPL has produced hundreds of poetry events & 700 hours of interview programming with legendary poets & whole systems activists. https://PaulENelson.com
elements.work:
Poet, interviewer, apprentice spiritual ecologist. https://cascadiapoeticslab.org/cascadia-poetry-festival-7/ October 6-8, 2023.

https://cascadiapoeticslab.org/category/podcast/

https://cascadiapoeticslab.org/watershed-press-home/ Cascadian Zen, Vol I, now available. Launch, Oct 6-8, 2023 at CPF7.
elements.statement: I have been aware of bioregionalism since the mid-90s when I interviewed Peter Berg. That my organization exists at the intersection of place and poetics I think is rather potent. See both of my websites for more information. A lot more content and information.

elements.label: david burman
elements.bio:
- early adopter/ promoter of LETSystem in Toronto 1990-1998
- co-chair Regenerating Toronto
- active in promoting indigenous world view
- involved in u-school for awareness based systems transformation
elements.work: tbd

elements.label: Tricia Stapleton
elements.bio: I am a resident of the Osa Peninsula Bioregion in the watershed of the Gulfo Dulce…As a community weaver interested in connecting our small bioregion into a larger network of other activated bioregions I have had the honor of working with a number of key players in the Regenerate Cascadia activation through the Earth Regenerators Network.
elements.where: Puerto Jimenez, Osa Peninsula, Costa Rica
elements.statement: I believe in the strength of biomimicry and as such know that by weaving across bioregions to inform, inspire and connect we are stronger than if working in isolation.

elements.label: Jan Inglis
elements.bio: I live in the Upper Columbia Kootenay bioregion and also spend time in Victoria.  I have been involved in bioregionalism , sustainability, climate education, public engagement and community animation since the 1980's.both in grassroots and academic   spheres.  I also have been an Integrative Body Psychotherapist practitioner and teacher for many years. My MSc is in Holistic Science focused on Deliberative Democracy and my PhD focused on Commons Governance and Economics.  I have been active with Earth Regenerators for almost 3 years.

elements.label: Jan Inglis
elements.bio: I live in the Upper Columbia Kootenay bioregion and also spend time in Victoria.  I have been involved in bioregionalism , sustainability, climate education, public engagement and community animation since the 1980's.both in grassroots and academic   spheres.  I also have been an Integrative Body Psychotherapist practitioner and teacher for many years. My MSc is in Holistic Science focused on Deliberative Democracy and my PhD focused on Commons Governance and Economics.  After working for many years trying to understand why we seemed so challenged in making the choices that would help us overcome the challenges which faced us I began to study adult cognitive development  and methods of scaffolding collective evolution. I have been active with Earth Regenerators for almost 3 years.

elements.label: Jan Inglis
elements.bio: I live in the Upper Columbia Kootenay bioregion and also spend time in Victoria.  I have been involved in bioregionalism , sustainability, climate education, public engagement and community animation since the 1980's.both in grassroots and academic   spheres.  I also have been an Integrative Body Psychotherapist practitioner and teacher for many years. My MSc is in Holistic Science focused on Deliberative Democracy and my PhD focused on Commons Governance and Economics.  After working for many years trying to understand why we seemed so challenged in making the choices that would help us overcome the challenges which faced us I began to study adult cognitive development  and methods of scaffolding collective evolution. I have been active with Earth Regenerators for almost 3 years.

elements.label: Shera Potka
elements.bio: Hello! I'm Shera Potka, a Computer Science PhD student hailing from the University of Victoria. My academic journey revolves around Data Analysis within Recommender Systems and Large Language Models. When I'm not diving into the world of research, I find solace in Web Design—a passion nurtured during my undergrad and grad years in Germany, where I delved into Media Computer Science. Crafting web identities is more than a hobby; it's a testament to the significance of a digital presence.
elements.work: I specialize in the intricate realm of Data Analysis, particularly within Recommender Systems and Large Language Models. My work involves unraveling patterns in vast datasets to enhance recommendations and the capabilities of language models. Through rigorous research and innovation, I strive to harness the power of data and language to create smarter, more efficient systems for various applications. It's a thrilling journey of discovery and problem-solving that keeps me deeply engaged in the world of computer science.
elements.statement: I think as a web designer, you play a vital role in promoting Cascadia Bioregion by creating online platforms that raise awareness, support local businesses, engage communities, and drive advocacy for a sustainable future.

elements.label: Joy Shayne Laughter
elements.work:
At heart I am a fiction writer, stepping into speculative or fantasy genres to live out choices that happen when doing the right thing looks totally wrong. I look for the discarded and rejected elements of a situation or society to find action pathways in fiction; the people everyone ignores, the tasks or objects that seem trivial hold the answers my characters seek. Be kind to ugly old women and listen to toads.

In non-fiction, in reporting and interviewing, find the kindest way in. Be a calm support to people speaking of troublesome topics.
elements.statement: I hope to find support for an alternative talk show that can be put out on broadcast radio as well as streaming and podcast, to increase the reach of bioregional topics in the Salish Sea area. It is possible, I feel, for community radio stations to be loosely networked with 5- to 15-minute modules of bioregional topics and voices.

elements.label: Rich Jensen
elements.work: Through critical listening and radical inclusion I have opened horizons, providing successful cultural development strategies for artists, brands and campaigns across diverse disciplines including music, publishing, social movements, product design and technology.

elements.label: Nicole Cousino
elements.work: We're creating a physical and social platform for regenerative practices that encourage an inclusive approach to building community, investigating the possible and engaging in continual learning for ourselves and others. We see our efforts as one node in a broader mobilization around regeneration, resiliency and thriving ecosystems.
elements.statement: I believe for true transformation to happen, many need to be part of the collective effort. And we strongly believe in the power of community and collaboration, whether that be local or distributed across physical and social geographies.

elements.label: Brian Kerkvliet
elements.work:
As a co-steward of Inspiration Farm for the past 20 + years, Brian has a wide breadth of practical knowledge on how to partner with natural systems to bring forth stability and abundance.

Being interested in gardening and appropriate technology since I was a kid, I have followed a path towards a regenerative lifestyle. Inspired by my grandpa Jerry who ran an integrated farm on  South Whidbey island. He was visited by Bill Mollison in the early 70's. After taking many short workshops on animals, grafting, gardening etc. my wife took a PDC with the Bullock brothers which I visited often. We held a PDC in 2009 here at Inspiration Farm featuring Robin Francis and Doug Bullock as instructors among others.

Inspiration Farm is an 13 acre homestead styled farm since 1994. Integrating Biodynamic and Permaculture practices in relation to annual & perennial food systems, animal husbandry, appropriate technology, land/water nutrient management. Currently we have 1.5 acres in annual production and 2 acres of fruit, nut and other perennials. We have chickens, milk cow, goats and raise turkeys and pigs most years. Our vision at Inspiration Farm is to co-create an environment to experiment and learn methods of creative and regenerative, resilient thriving.

Biodynamic farming is a type of organic farming that incorporates an understanding of natural dynamic forces not yet fully understood by science. By working creatively with these subtle energies, we are able to significantly enhance the health of our farm affecting the quality of the soil, nutrition and flavor of the food grown.

Throughout the year we have a variety of Events, Tours and Workshops. This year we are hosting several workshops on permaculture and sustainable practices. Contact us if you would like to be notified on workshops that we will be hosting or would like to bring a group for a experiential farm tour.

Are you interested in taking a Permaculture Design Certificate Course? We want to hear from you.  619 E Laurel rd.

Bellingham Wa 98226

360-319--2029

elements.label: Marcia Drake
elements.work: My passion is using data to solve real world problems and to save lives. I have an interest in networks, processes, emergency management and risk mitigation, economics, strategic planning and data-driven decision-making. I also have a love for nature based solutions having grown up playing in the wilderness of the Pacific Northwest.
elements.statement: I have a lot of skills to contribute to the cause

elements.label: Gabriel Lavalle
elements.work: I currently work in horticulture for several private residences around the Puget sound area
elements.statement: Would prefer not write a novel. I care. I know what is happening. I want to do what I can.

elements.label: Natalie Bade
elements.bio: I'm a fake account used for testing.

elements.label: Lansing Scott
elements.bio: Learned about bioregionalism from Planet Drum & Gary Snyder while in college. Worked at RAIN magazine after college, which helped grow the Cascadia bioregional movement. Got involved in organizing Cascadia bioregional congresses after attending the first one in 1986 at Evergreen State College. Was lead organizer for the Bioregional Congress of Pacific Cascadia at Breitenbush in 1988, & the Mish Bioregional Gathering at Deception Pass in 1990. Been involved in various indy media projects since working at RAIN, including the Portland Alliance, Seattle Community Catalyst, the Seattle Independent Media Center, Eat the State!, & Catalytic Community. Was grateful to see the Cascadian bioregional resurgence in the 21st century, & connected with Brandon Letsinger several years ago to see how I could be of service. Helped launch Cascadia Spoke.
elements.work: Since 1990 I've worked as an independent contractor under the business name Catalytic Communications. Tagline: Affordable communications for a change. My work mostly serves progressive organizations, artists, & small business owners in communicating their messages effectively & affordably, in print and online.
elements.statement: Any viable future in Cascadia will need be bioregional, seems to me. We need to live rooted in place, and need to align all our institutions and cultural practices in harmony with the nature of our place.

elements.label: Ben Moseley
elements.bio: 20 Year background in internet consulting, marketing and development. Working towards building a sustainable livelihood in community with others. Currently, getting my permaculture design course certificate through OSU>
